Description: Steve: Please review each topic and add your thoughts in the Your_Comments column. Update Status if you have a decision. Claude will then respond in Claude_Comments column. And to keep going to the next columns for further interactions.
What columns does your current CSV have when working with Claude Code? Share an example or describe the structure.
Claude_Comments: PERFECT! We'll use this CSV as the template. Final structure: ID (UUID), Topic, Description, Status, Priority, Category, Date_Created, Date_Updated, Your_Comments, Claude_Comments (+ more comment columns as needed). Instructions will tell AI to update Date_Updated.
User Comments: There isn't a proper one.We make them up each time. This is the first time we are thinking formally. This makes sense but we need to tell AI to uipdate the Date Updated column each time.

Description: You said: Claude 1, User 1, Claude 2, User 2 etc. Should we: (A) Add new columns each round (Claude_1, User_1, Claude_2...) or (B) Keep 2 columns and append with timestamps?
Claude_Comments: RECOMMENDATION: Add new columns each round (Your_Comments, Claude_Comments, Your_Comments_2, Claude_Comments_2, etc). SIMPLER for AI to update (just add to new column vs parsing existing). Date_Updated tracks when row changed. In DB, we'll store each comment with timestamp. CSV = simple for Claude Code, DB = rich data for app.
User Comments: I thought it's  just easier to add columns each time. But u know tech better.But if we update the same cell each time, it's harder to read so maybe it's also harder for AI to update properly. Which makes me think should we have a date and time for each comment?We probably need it for the database. So that would be even more columns. Think and come back to me. Remember I'm not a developer so I don't know tech well know to know implocations

Description: Should app: (A) Watch file automatically and notify when CSV changes, (B) User clicks 'Check for Updates' button, (C) Both options available?
Claude_Comments: PERFECT! Checking every 30 secs is negligible resources. We'll add: (1) Auto-check with configurable interval (default 30s), (2) Manual "Refresh" button, (3) Settings to disable auto-check or change interval. Toast notification when changes detected.
User Comments: Does it really use a lot of resources to check say every 30 secs?But also need a manual option to update. Also user can set how often to check or not at all. That way I can turn it off when I don't need it

Description: If Claude messes up column order should we: (A) Auto-detect columns by name (flexible), (B) Enforce strict order and show error, (C) Auto-fix and re-export?
Claude_Comments: AGREED! Parse by column name, not position. Much more robust. We'll also validate on import - if column name missing or wrong, show clear error message with what we expected vs what we found.
User Comments: Agree if we don't make a mistake

Description: Build as: (A) Electron desktop app (works offline, file system access, quick build), (B) Next.js web app (upload/download CSV, hosted), (C) VS Code extension for Claude Code?
Claude_Comments: DECISION: Next.js with local server (like your other app). You're familiar with it, we can use SQLite/Turso for DB, and it's just as fast to build as Electron. Extension = sidebar in Claude Code IDE but more limited. Next.js = full control, can add AI later.

Also u create code so quickly so does it matter really if it's Electorn or Next.js. My other app uses Next amd I run a local server

Description: Where to put AI instructions: (A) First row of CSV with [INSTRUCTIONS] marker, (B) Separate .txt file (issues_instructions.txt), (C) Built into app (user doesn't see it)?
Claude_Comments: AGREED! First row with [INSTRUCTIONS] marker. Keeps everything in one file. Easy to see and edit. App will parse this row specially and include in export.
User Comments: A for now. We could change later.But it's easier to give a CSV to Code with no additional text.

Description: Track dates for: (A) Created + Updated, (B) Just Updated, (C) No dates?
Claude_Comments: CONFIRMED! Date_Created (when topic first added) and Date_Updated (last modification). Both stored in CSV and DB. Shown in UI.

Description: When importing updated CSV with existing IDs: (A) Update existing topics, (B) Keep both versions, (C) Ask user what to do?
Claude_Comments: PERFECT! UUIDs for IDs. Same UUID = update existing topic. New row from AI = app generates UUID and saves to CSV. User adds row = app adds UUID before saving. Simple sync logic!
User Comments: Let's use UUIDs if that's OK. And the idea is if we get a CSVwith the same IDs then we know to update. When AI sends a new row, we add a UUID. If the user adds a new row/topic, we add the UUID to the csv before saving

Description: When exporting CSV after you've made changes in app: (A) Overwrite original CSV, (B) Create new file (issues_v2.csv), (C) Ask user?
Claude_Comments: GOOD APPROACH! Export flow: (1) Create backup (filename_backup_timestamp.csv), (2) Overwrite original file. User just tells Claude Code "look at updated csv" and it reads same filename. Safe and simple!
User Comments: Create backup of old but update same file so Claude knows to pick it up.In Claude I can just say "look at updated csv file" as the only prompt, unless u can automate it which u mentioned above

Description: Should instructions be: (A) Fixed template in app, (B) User can edit before export, (C) Saved templates (template 1: review, template 2: implement)?
Claude_Comments: GREAT IDEA! App will have 3-5 templates (Review, Implement, Prioritize, Decide). User can select, edit before export, and save custom templates. Instructions go in INST row (row 1). Simple and flexible!

Description: Can user edit topics in the app? (A) Yes - edit any field, (B) Yes - only comments, (C) Read-only - edit in CSV only?
Claude_Comments: CLEAR RULES! User can edit: (1) Status/Priority/Category always, (2) Your_Comments always, (3) Topic/Description ONLY when first created (lock after first export to Claude). Date fields auto-updated. Claude_Comments read-only. Makes sense!
